fr:title.text: Chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field reduces an ACC (C_k, d) to a smaller one, which can be explicitly described. Its cells are the critical cells in C_k. For the faces of a cell \sigma , we start with the faces d(\sigma ) in the original ACC. Then we move every non-critical cell down along the discrete field lines, up to some sign flips, until we get to a critical cell.

Note that the field lines alternate between n- and (n+1)-dimensional cells, and we count the movement n – (n+1) – n as a single step. Also, discrete field lines can branch and merge, and the cells need to duplicate and move down every branch.

fr:title.text: Discrete Vector Fields and Fundamental Algebraic Topology

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Discrete Vector Fields and Fundamental Algebraic Topology

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We show in this text how the most important homology equivalences of fundamental Algebraic Topology can be obtained as reductions associated to discrete vector fields. Mainly the homology equivalences whose existence — most often non-constructive — is proved by the main spectral sequences, the Serre and Eilenberg-Moore spectral sequences. On the contrary, the constructive existence is here systematically looked for and obtained.

fr:title.text: Chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given an admissible discrete vector field on an algebraic cellular complex (C_k, d), we can generate a chain reduction. It will be computable when the cellular complex is effective.

The DVF partitions the chain groups into a direct sum C_k^{s} \oplus C_k^t \oplus C_k^c, corresponding to source, target and critical cells. We would like to create a reduction to the critical cells only. To do this, we invoke perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction and start with a simpler chain reduction.

Consider the algebraic cellular complex whose chain groups are C_k, but the differential d'(\sigma ) = \pm \tau iff \overrightharpoon {\tau \sigma } is in the vector field, and zero otherwise. The sign is determined as the sign of \tau in d(\sigma ). Hence d' : C_{k+1}^{t} \to C_k^s, and is zero otherwise. Therefore using the characterization of chain reduction as a direct sum with a split exact chain complex, we see that this complex can be reduced to the complex on C_k^p whose differential is identically zero.

Next, we try to perturb d' to d. We need h_{\rho } \mathbin {\circ } (d' - d) to be locally nilpotent, where \rho is the reduction constructed above. h_{\rho } can be viewed as the inverse of d', as it maps the source cell to the target cell. Expanding the definition, we see that this map transports cells down the discrete field line. Since the vector field is admissible, such a transportation eventually terminates and it becomes zero.

fr:title.text: Discrete field lines can branch and merge

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Discrete field lines can branch and merge

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Although we make an analogy between a discrete vector field and a vector field, the field lines of a DVF may branch out. For instance, take a triangle \tau with three edges \sigma _1, \sigma _2, \sigma _3. We can have a vector \overrightharpoon {\sigma _1 \tau } pointing into the triangle, and \sigma _2, \sigma _3 each having vectors pointing out. Similarly multiple field lines may join when they reach a lower-degree cell. Because of this, we need to take care in the phrasing of admissibility.

Given a discrete vector field, the discrete version of field lines is defined as a sequence of cells alternating between degree p and (p-1) starting and ending with lower-degree cells, with a few requirements.

fr:ul.fr:li: When the degree increases, the two cells must occur as a vector in the DVF.
When the degree decreases, the degree (p-1) cell must be a (possible non-regular) face of the degree p cell.
Two degree (p-1) cells separated by a degree p cell must not be the same.
